content.description: Climb up thin cracks and horizontals up to the anchor shared with Spread Eagle.
content.protection: Crux is the bouldery start.  After that, there is some protection here and there.  The guidebook gives it an "R" rating.  Probably a better top rope than a lead.
content.location: Located just right of the bolted arete Spread Eagle.

content.description:
fun stemming with hand jams.

Tuolumne style knobs at the traverse leads into pinpoint feet

Headwall lightens up but requires some flexibility

A cool 3 pitch route which climbs up an arete and then up interesting face climbing to the top. I think alot of people just do the first pitch (5.9 three bolts and some gear) which goes up to an anchor you can see from the ground.  You can also walk up a ramp to get to this anchor to top rope Spread Eagle and Welcome to Lost Eagle.  The 2nd pitch is 5.7 and fun with  5 bolts and some gear.  The last pitch is 5.7, slabby, and has two bolts and some gear to a bolted anchor on the summit block.
content.location: located in the middle of the Gold Block Right Side.

climbs.name: Simpler Times
climbs.fa: Bob Steed, Dan Merrick, Ford Merrick, Bob Hill

content.description: This is the furthest right route at Lost Eagle.  Climbs up a white streak/water chute/groove.
content.protection: Five bolts to a poor gear anchor.  The crux moves are low angle "no hold" type moves above the bolts.  The climbing ends at a horizontal "crack" system on a part of the slab that is covered with debris;...large dead tree branches, etc.  Looks like 1/2 of a dead tree slide down the slab, fell apart more, and is just hanging about above Simpler Times.  The debris could be cleaned up with some effort, time and care, but as for now;..it's dangerous and unfortunate.  Walk off right or slab up another 80 feet of easy and unprotected climbing to a visible bolted anchor.
content.location: far right side of lost eagle

content.description: Technical face to an easy finish. Enjoy!
content.location: This route is located on the main Gold Black wall. The start is below a large boulder. Climb up the boulder and launch onto the technical face. This route is the middle bolted line on the face.

climbs.name: A God In An Alcove
climbs.fa: Dave Daly, Roger Hayashi and Gerry Jessurun (June 2009)

content.description: Tricky friction slab leads to an easy short headwall.
content.location: Far left of the Gold block right side. Obvious bolted route up the slab.
